E10A3DA25CFE469E8E786852E2B269DE.description: MAGE.B.52: apply the Addition Rule, P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B), and interpret the answer in context

D3484E57531B4E66B0A71066C3AD0EDC.description: MAGE.B.51: find the conditional probability of A given B as the fraction of B's outcomes that also belong to A, and interpret the answer in context

808FDC683EFD44D398F6203667236C8E.description: MAGE.B.50: recognize and explain the concepts of conditional probability and independence in everyday language and everyday situations (e.g., compare the chance of having lung cancer if you are a smoker with the chance of being a smoker if you have lung cancer)

E488ECE40C3F4E86A13C51D4AAE6C74A.description: MAGE.B.49: construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data when two categories are associated with each object being classified; use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are independent and to approximate conditional probabilities (e.g., collect data from a random sample of students in your school on their favorite subject among math, science, and English; estimate the probability that a randomly selected student from your school will favor science given that the student is in tenth grade; do the same for other subjects and compare the results)

0208A38C8D304424B6BA630ED2A149F7.description: MAGE.B.48: understand the conditional probability of A given B as P(A and B)/P(B); interpret independence of A and B in terms of conditional probability (i.e., the conditional probability of A given B is the same as the probability of A and the conditional probability of B given A is the same as the probability of B)

841C107D47434B92A3669B7B6A331066.description: MAGE.B.47: understand that if two events A and B are independent, the probability of A and B occurring together is the product of their probabilities, and that if the probability of two events A and B occurring together is the product of their probabilities, the two events are independent

A8C1C568416A450CA7F7684B8A30DB8D.description: MAGE.B.46: describe categories of events as subsets of a sample space using unions, intersections, or complements of other events (i.e., "or," "and," "not")

31A010A532664A77807A8999CBACF6F4.description: MAGE.A.45: apply geometric methods to solve design problems (e.g., designing an object or structure to satisfy physical constraints or minimize cost; working with typographic grid systems based on ratios)

FBB7707C18A84B749AA41F0902D4552F.description: MAGE.A.44: apply concepts of density based on area and volume in modeling situations (e.g., persons per square mile, BTUs per cubic foot)

AFBD313A4C884810A75018FE6C4CBB13.description: MAGE.A.43: use geometric shapes, their measures, and their properties to describe objects (e.g., modeling a tree trunk or a human torso as a cylinder)

44E842B07E7E444DB7F2E5416D1E26A1.description: MAGE.A.42: apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths in right triangles in real-world and mathematical problems in three dimensions

0308CA4AE4164E9E98BB72F2CE282DFD.description: MAGE.A.41: identify the shapes of two-dimensional cross-sections of three-dimensional objects, and identify three-dimensional objects generated by rotations of two-dimensional objects

9E24803CA230470E98FCA6F9F8FBC696.description: MAGE.A.40: use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles (e.g., using the distance formula)

57DF06C30A0641BDADA0A53B7DE22DC2.description: MAGE.A.39: find the point on a directed line segment between two given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio

A81F7ACE48B042BE86AB304BFDA4A29D.description: MAGE.A.38: prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point)

4FA2079A91DE46BBB6674880A2AD0959.description: MAGE.A.37: use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically (i.e., prove or disprove that a figure defined by four given points in the coordinate plane is a rectangle; prove or disprove that a point lies on a circle centered at the origin and containing a given point), including quadrilaterals, circles, right triangles, and parabolas

DAADD2BB9C024352A230028DD308ABD2.description: MAGE.A.36: explain and apply the distance formula as an application of the Pythagorean Theorem

6D656F3DCD384BC6B7602D594D3A0B0F.description: MAGE.A.35: use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems

B270AE9E03644F47921496F41B51B6FF.description: MAGE.A.34: give an informal argument using Cavalieri's principle for the formulas of the volume of a sphere and other solid figures

A1CA26E5DC994DACB138EEE69A0B85AD.description: MAGE.A.33: give informal arguments for geometric formulas (i.e., informal arguments for the formulas of the circumference of a circle and area of a circle using dissection arguments and informal limit arguments; informal arguments for the formula of the volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone using Cavalieri's principle)

F1C75F4706A14F92B1D68701256DC00E.description: MAGE.A.32: derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius using the Pythagorean Theorem; complete the square to find the center and radius of a circle given by an equation

8FD8FAB7B9BE448CAE1CB1A9A17E805B.description: MAGE.A.31: derive using similarity the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector

0E0F109E2D0B4C689E3DDFB815570B28.description: MAGE.A.30: construct a tangent line from a point outside a given circle to the circle

56D511D4D1AA49098E4882026709D1D8.description: MAGE.A.29: prove properties of angles for a quadrilateral inscribed in a circle

6E1FD30CD5A1478192884D70014C4495.description: MAGE.A.28: identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, chords, tangents, and secants (i.e., the relationship between central, inscribed, and circumscribed angles; inscribed angles on a diameter are right angles; the radius of a circle is perpendicular to the tangent where the radius intersects the circle)

21C27238CDD947ACA0A30F2E7B9D60A6.description: MAGE.A.27: prove that all circles are similar (i.e., using transformations; ratio of circumference to the diameter is a constant)

2EF2BC88844A4C2D9C22A4E0612DA3FC.description: MAGE.A.26: use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems

456787534F274BDEBFA2750898428C72.description: MAGE.A.25: explain and use the relationship between the sine and cosine of complementary angles

066909960FF34AE985FC07AB7F353DE2.description: MAGE.A.24: understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles

11AA42C7F7D94F3B882725B194D46701.description: MAGE.A.23: use similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures

D163144C4E7E414AB321FD8272ADEA9E.description: MAGE.A.22: prove theorems about triangles (i.e., a line parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two proportionally, and conversely; the Pythagorean Theorem using triangle similarity)

0A1A202CA775473B9CB1032C55972F52.description: MAGE.A.21: use the properties of similarity transformations to establish the AA criterion for two triangles to be similar

6950756BCE1C4782A7F0F63351EA0ADC.description: MAGE.A.20: given two figures, use the definition of similarity in terms of similarity transformations to decide if they are similar; explain using similarity transformations the meaning of similarity for triangles as the equality of all corresponding pairs of angles and the proportionality of all corresponding pairs of sides

0F25F8286F3D4261B003B9B182644698.description: MAGE.A.19: verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor (i.e., a dilation of a line not passing through the center of the dilation results in a parallel line and leaves a line passing through the center unchanged; the dilation of a line segment is longer or shorter according to the ratio given by the scale factor)

3BB3FDDAF27640519482FCBB65F576CA.description: MAGE.A.18: use congruence criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures

767713CA774E420D8F361DC82DC7C308.description: MAGE.A.17: prove theorems about parallelograms (i.e., opposite sides are congruent, opposite angles are congruent, the diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other, and conversely, rectangles are parallelograms with congruent diagonals)

E5ACC71FBEA341EDB2C79922D08EF060.description: MAGE.A.16: prove theorems about triangles (i.e., measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180 degrees; base angles of isosceles triangles are congruent; the segment joining midpoints of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and half the length; the medians of a triangle meet at a point)

4FF59032823E4A62BF2BE28091E93116.description: MAGE.A.15: informally prove the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse geometrically (i.e., using area model)

052321D68E0D4E73A3555A3C22BA38C0.description: MAGE.A.14: construct the inscribed and circumscribed circle of a triangle

F271E50E89D3422F938601A42C5EA90E.description: MAGE.A.13: prove theorems about lines and angles (i.e., vertical angles are congruent; when a transversal crosses parallel lines, alternate interior angles are congruent and corresponding angles are congruent; points on a perpendicular bisector of a line segment are exactly those equidistant from the segment's endpoints)

C85E2BB8E5924623B2B2CA38C071EC17.description: MAGE.A.12: use informal arguments to establish facts about the angle sum and exterior angles of triangles and about the angles created when parallel lines are cut by a transversal

7C78F288AA964849AD10BE64886F3AF7.description: MAGE.A.11: explain how the criteria for triangle congruence (i.e., ASA, SAS, SSS, HL, AAS) follow from the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions

8FEC5A71ECE84A9E82346628385E3A56.description: MAGE.A.10: use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent

D379B4D4A2DB4C88B88F444457BB2C58.description: MAGE.A.9: use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure; given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to decide if they are congruent

659B397EF6B34E3785F397E291A8E4AC.description: MAGE.A.8: develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and translations in terms of angles, circles, perpendicular lines, parallel lines, and line segments

A0F25B10D27D409E8FFF34531CD70F26.description: MAGE.A.7: describe the rotations and reflections that carry a rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or regular polygon onto itself

82C726D1FC0F47E69297C6D923D2F0EF.description: MAGE.A.6: given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software; specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another

F75A0DF3CF4C43B1BD929B44EE2BC63F.description: MAGE.A.5: describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs; compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch)

CD519E049A854C19B6D21EFF21566026.description: MAGE.A.4: describe the effects of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on two-dimensional figures using coordinates

4121B27317834C19BC0E8C91AB01656E.description: MAGE.A.3: know and apply the precise definitions of angle, circle, perpendicular line, parallel line, and line segment, based on the undefined notions of point, line, distance along a line, and distance around a circular arc

BAE9EAEFFCD8491DB85B0B41EB196A78.description: MAGE.A.2: construct an equilateral triangle, a square, and a regular hexagon, each inscribed in a circle

FD0AE6B2198D4D39B655A9B84284F901.description: MAGE.A.1: make formal geometric constructions with a variety of tools and methods (e.g., compass and straightedge, string, reflective devices, paper folding, dynamic geometric software); copying a segment; copying an angle; bisecting a segment; bisecting an angle; constructing perpendicular lines, including the perpendicular bisector of a line segment; and constructing a line parallel to a given line through a point not on the line
